text: Hi everyone! Does anyone have any advice on how to implement a content approval workflow? We’re a small team (everyone does a little bit of everything), so the four eyes principle has typically been enough. However, we’re starting to publish more content and it’s getting difficult to keep content consistent in quality, voice, and information. Even though I’m the senior content marketer in the team, I hesitate to take the role of being the one who green-lights any content that gets published (from landing pages to blog posts), but I feel it might be the only way to ensure quality content going forward since not everyone in the team is a strong writer.

elements.text: Hi everyone! Does anyone have any advice on how to implement a content approval workflow? We’re a small team (everyone does a little bit of everything), so the four eyes principle has typically been enough. However, we’re starting to publish more content and it’s getting difficult to keep content consistent in quality, voice, and information. Even though I’m the senior content marketer in the team, I hesitate to take the role of being the one who green-lights any content that gets published (from landing pages to blog posts), but I feel it might be the only way to ensure quality content going forward since not everyone in the team is a strong writer.

text:
Hi <@U012BUUPHFT>! I’ve been where you’ve been, and you have my sympathies. Working with a “lean team” while being pulled in multiple different directions yourself can be very frustrating.

I, ultimately, made the decision (and it was a little thrust upon me) to be final approver for all content on a small team. I think the biggest lesson learned was that, even if you’re a final approver, all responsibility doesn’t fall on you to make sure every piece is perfect. It still takes teamwork, even if you’re a final approver. And people who are not strong writers (yet!) should still be expected to help in the process. Here’s what helped me:

1. Implement self-editing into your content process. This can be done really well using checklists that include things like: 
    a.  Run your writing through the Grammarly app. 
    b. Check your writing against the company style guide. 
    c. Read your work out loud.
I have a few different checklists I’ve used in the past if you’re interested in seeing those.

2. Implement peer-editing into your content process. Before any piece of writing falls on your desk, it needs to be looked at by another writer/editor/marketer.

3. Now, this is important one that adds time, but IS SO IMPORTANT….Have the content piece by reviewed again once it’s in staging. If it’s web copy, review it once more once it’s on the website in staging. If it’s a report, review it all again after the final copy is in the report design.

Depending on the piece, I’ve sometimes left this in-design review to another trusted colleague, mostly because I’ve been very close to it up to this point, but for larger projects, I always review it here, too.

4. If you don’t have a project/content management system to track all of this, it’s really helpful for accountability and visbility.

If your small team is producing more and more content, it will most likely begin to lengthen the time it takes to produce a piece because you’re including these checks and balances into your system. That’s ok! Leadership will either accept the lengthier process after you show them your commitment to quality. Or they’ll still want it fast, but they’ll see a need for more people on your team. Hopefully. :slightly_smiling_face:

Let me know if you have any questions or if you want to chat more!!

It still takes teamwork, even if you’re a final approver. And people who are not strong writers (yet!) should still be expected to help in the process. Here’s what helped me:
Implement self-editing into your content process. This can be done really well using checklists that include things like:
Run your writing through the Grammarly app.

2. Implement peer-editing into your content process. Before any piece of writing falls on your desk, it needs to be looked at by another writer/editor/marketer.

Depending on the piece, I’ve sometimes left this in-design review to another trusted colleague, mostly because I’ve been very close to it up to this point, but for larger projects, I always review it here, too.

4. If you don’t have a project/content management system to track all of this, it’s really helpful for accountability and visbility.

text: I would also encourage people in your team to lean on editing and writing tools (hemingway, as well as a strong company style guide and grammarly as Ashly suggests) in order to make sure that ‘simple’ edits and corrections are happening earlier on in the process. For team members who require a little more support, its also super important to provide feedback earlier on (I love <https://twitter.com/derek_gleason/status/1306273615973933061|this tweet thread> by <@UJDPMTREY>!). That should hopefully mean that your ‘green light’ checks can be just that, and not another round of lengthy revisions.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/derek_gleason|@derek_gleason>: Outlines are potential energy.

As an editor, you're inspiring a writer to create something great.

Any critique is hypothetical—you're not dogging past work but sharing enthusiasm for what something could be (while also steering them clear of potential pitfalls).
attachments.text:

text: My teams at Adwerx and Propel PLM used a "marketing-qa" channel where approval was distributed. We had a Zap create a Slack "ticket" whenever the QA tag i created was added to a task in Asana. Anyone on the marketing team could claim it by reacting with the :eyes: emoji. There was a checklist for each type of content (alt text, meta desc, etc) that anyone could do. This was meant to be used as a CYA measure before hitting send on a big email campaign and saved the team from getting held up when someone was out sick. The QAer would add comments or feedback in the Slack thread and then mark it with a :white_check_mark:  when it was ready to publish. All credit to John Wall at Adwerx for conceptualizing this. I just stole it :joy:

text: Who has a great intake form/process for their internal "clients"? We get so many requests and need to be more disciplined about the information we collect the expectations we set, etc. We're a marketing team and most of our requests are content and design oriented.

text: Has anyone paid a research firm for market/user/reader research? I'm not looking to do anything massive (i.e. Gartner/Forrester) but I want to explore the practicalities of researching how a particular reader segment reads, buys, and makes decisions without doing the leg work myself.

elements.text: Has anyone paid a research firm for market/user/reader research? I'm not looking to do anything massive (i.e. Gartner/Forrester) but I want to explore the practicalities of researching how a particular reader segment reads, buys, and makes decisions without doing the leg work myself.

text: Ha! Not an option for us. We support several teams.

elements.text: Ha! Not an option for us. We support several teams.

text:
I would also recommend building in some
sort of way to grade drafts as they come in. Could be A-E, could be more like “excellent, acceptable, required major revisions, etc” (We actually put a field for this in Airtable). Eventually you start to see which writers are consistently delivering close-to-finished work and which writers need more coaching to get to that level. Once you have someone who is getting close to perfect every time ... maybe that person can start taking some of the editing off your plate.

text: My team does as I also run Creative Services (so not specific to blog posts, but all creative requests). I can connect you with our Creative Services Manager if you want to learn more. For us the trick has been not just getting an intake down but getting visibility into the requests and also empowering stakeholders to self-serve smaller requests (combination of quarterly planning and a lot of training... constant WIP)
